Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grants for Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security 2012

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS) brings together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in human computer interaction, security, and privacy. The program features technical papers, workshops and tutorials, a poster session, panels and invited talks, and discussion sessions. The eighth SOUPS will be held July 11-13, 2012 at the AAAS building in Washington, DC. The funds support travel grants for students to attend the conference. SOUPS is the top conference devoted to usable privacy and security. By increasing student participation at the SOUPS conference, it may encourage more students to get involved in usable security research and pursue further graduate education and careers in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS) brings together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in human computer interaction, security, and privacy. The program features technical papers, workshops and tutorials, a poster session, panels and invited talks, and discussion sessions. The eighth SOUPS was held July 11-13, 2012 at the AAAS building in Washington, DC.

SOUPS is a unique, interdisciplinary conference that focuses on an important aspect of computer security and privacy that is often overlooked by traditional security researchers. The conference has played an important role as a catalyst that has helped foster interdisciplinary collaborations and encouraged more researchers to enter this field.

In 2012, SOUPS was attended by 190 people. There were 14 papers and 27 posters presented in the main conference. In addition 11 short papers were presented as part of the workshop on the first day of SOUPS. All papers are available on the conference website http://cups.cs.cmu.edu/soups/2012/

The conference also included a keynote talk from FTC Commissioner Julie Brill and a panel on Institutional Review Boards.

NSF funding funded travel scholarships for 11 students and registration scholarships for 27 students. Students attended from Carnegie Mellon University, Dartmouth College, Naval Post-Graduate School, Northwestern University, Pennsylvania State University, University of California Berkeley, University of California Irvine, University of North Carolina Charlotte, University of Notre Dame. Six scholarship participants were female.
